nodes.text: PCA-based dimensionality reduction improves machine learning performance and efficiency for estimating soil moisture from hyperspectral optical imaging data
Hyperspectral optical imaging produces high-dimensional, strongly correlated spectral data that hinder model training and generalization (curse of dimensionality)

Principal Component Analysis (PCA) is a simple, interpretable, and computationally efficient linear method to transform correlated spectral features into uncorrelated components ordered by explained variance
A Random Forest regression model can be used to quantify predictive performance for estimating continuous soil moisture from hyperspectral features

The dataset contains 679 samples, each with soil moisture target and 125 hyperspectral bands recorded from 450 to 950 nm, collected from a bare-soil field campaign with reference moisture measured by a TRIME-PICO sensor
PCA was applied after standardizing spectral features with StandardScaler and implemented with sklearn.decomposition.PCA; components were selected to retain more than 99 percent of total variance
Data were split into training and test sets with test size 0.3 and fixed random state 42 to ensure reproducibility
Exploratory analysis showed soil moisture values ranged approximately 25 to 43 percent and were concentrated near 32 percent, indicating a moderately narrow target distribution
RandomForestRegressor was trained with 100 trees, random state 42, and performance measured by coefficient of determination R2
Covariance matrix analysis, eigenvalue distribution, and a scree plot all indicate that the first two principal components capture the dominant variance in the data
Standardization and PCA projection enable lower-dimensional visualization that can reveal structure and separation related to soil moisture
Variance ratios: PC1 = 0.9889, PC2 = 0.0064; cumulative variance after PC2 = 0.9953 (> 99 percent), while PC3 and higher contribute negligible variance
Projection onto PC1 and PC2 shows clearer clustering of samples by soil moisture than higher-component projections (e.g., PC2 vs PC3), indicating improved separability in two-component space
The Random Forest trained on PCA-transformed features achieved R2 = 0.947, explaining approximately 94.7 percent of soil moisture variance

Conclusion: PCA reducing 125 bands to two components retained over 99 percent variance, reduced redundancy, improved visualization and computational efficiency, and preserved strong predictive accuracy for soil moisture estimation

Limitation and future work: Results are demonstrated on a single ground dataset and baseline PCA; evaluation of alternative feature extraction methods and across diverse sensors and scenarios is needed
